Post_Title: Religious affiliation in the USA has declined and that is beneficial to societies because people focus on now instead of after they die.
post_text:
Americans who are members of a church, synagogue or mosque are not in the majority, according to a [Gallup report](https://news.gallup.com/poll/341963/church-membership-falls-below-majority-first-time.aspx). Less than 47% of Americans belong to a religious congregation compared to 1945, when more than 75% of Americans belonged to a religious congregation. This is the sharpest recorded decline in American history.

Research shows that secular people are more likely to support women’s [reproductive rights](https://news.gallup.com/poll/154946/non-christians-postgrads-highly-pro-choice.aspx), [universal healthcare](https://ffrf.org/news/news-releases/item/37966-ffrf-releases-major-secular-voter-poll-we-are-the-real-values-voters), [gay rights](https://www.pewforum.org/fact-sheet/changing-attitudes-on-gay-marriage/), [environmental protections](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4527763/), [death with dignity](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/0030222817715755), [gun safety legislation](https://ffrf.org/news/news-releases/item/37966-ffrf-releases-major-secular-voter-poll-we-are-the-real-values-voters) and treating [drug abuse](https://www.barna.com/research/plurality-of-americans-favor-legalizing-marijuana/) as a medical rather than criminal problem — all of which will serve to increase dignity, liberty and well-being in America.They do not rely on a “God” to help them or wait for their reward after they die.

Non-religious are more likely to understand and respect the [scientific method](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0963662519888599), which results in their increased willingness to get vaccinated, for instance, and adhere to empirically grounded health recommendations, a rational orientation that saves lives. Secular people are also [more](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamapediatrics/fullarticle/205706) [supportive](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/14681811.2013.775063) of [sex education](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs13178-015-0187-8), which reduces unwanted pregnancies and sexually transmitted diseases.

Religion is a byproduct of the way our brains work, growing from cognitive tendencies to seek order from chaos, to anthropomorphize our environment and to believe the world around us was created for our use.Religion has survived because it helped us form increasingly larger social groups, held together by common beliefs.

Threads.Reply_Text: The god of the American liberal tends to be the state.

Replies.Reply_Text:
Aside from this being complete nonsense, I’m entertained by the fact that your brain immediately went to name “liberal” as the antithesis to religiosity.

This should give you some pause to reflect, as obviously you’re coming from a place of extreme biases.

I think the iron man version of his argument would be the concept of the [American Civil Religion](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_civil_religion), which does have *some* value as a lens of analysis despite being somewhat reductive. Of course, it's far more dominant among conservatives, but liberals (and most right-libertarians) also subscribe to it to a large extent.

Of course, ACL is far from the pointlessly reductive statement of having the state as a god; the worship of ACL is more to a specific American myth where the state is one aspect of several.

As someone who is both an atheist and against government I find it odd when people skeptical of religious authority demand secular authority via the state. They trade in bishops, priests, and pastors, in exchange for bureaucrats, law enforcement agencies, and politicians.

Specifically those who rave about the corruption of the police and then on the flip side demand the disarming of American civilians and the prohibition of self defense, for example.

I'm not a conservative. Far from it. I'm against abortion prohibition, I don't care if you're gay. I'm against the military industrial complex. Self defense is criminalized in some parts of America. Firstly, if you defend yourself against the police there will be hell to pay. A good example of this is the Breonna Taylor case. Her boyfriend, Kenneth Walker, fired at police when they invaded his home. He would have been charged had it not been for public outcry.

Another case recently involved a Bodega worker in New York. He killed someone who was trying to cause him bodily harm. He was arrested and the DA only dropped charges on the man for defending himself once public pressure mounted.

A branch of the criminalization of self defense came to light with the SCOTUS Bruen decision recently. It was determined in this case that states and localities could not make individuals have a stated purpose for needing to conceal carry a firearm and that licenses should be issued to people who fulfill basic requirements, such as not having a criminal record and being of age. The reason this matters is that many localities and even some states entirely, had conceal carry laws so restrictive  and corrupted that you could only obtain CCW permits if you had connections to the right people. This criminalized self defense for many who could not obtain the license to carry a firearm legally and risked legal trouble for attempting to carry a weapon.

>Voted third party in 2020

So you threw your vote in the garbage.  Cool.

You're libertarian (AKA "Conservative-lite")  The "abhorrence" of the ideas you mentioned are only abhorrent to people who ingest pretty wild propaganda, so you're flat out lying when you say you don't really ingest news. Frankly, I'm on the side of CCW being difficult to obtain.  I might change my mind if guns ever require proper training and licensing to own and operate, but until then, I don't support the general populous wandering around with deadly weapons in their pockets.  I grew up in the south, and would constantly have to leave house parties in high school because drunk assholes wanted to play with their fucking guns.  No surprise that they were pulled out during arguments, too.  Gun control isn't abhorrent. People are generally idiots.  Common sense gun control helps everyone.  It helps idiots make less mistakes, and can save lives.

Regarding the bodega dude, that's a pretty random and complicated event to cite for your cause.  Did you see the video?  He honestly did not need to stab the dude to death.  My feelings are pretty ambivalent towards it, but it is by no means a shining example of some kind of repressive criminalization of self defense.  The guy was an asshole, but he wasn't armed, and he got stabbed to death in the heart.  You chose probably the worst example to try to make a point with.

Third party votes are not throwing in the garbage. Anybody who has taken a basic political science course could tell you that historically and in the modern day, minor political parties play a role in the American electoral system.

Gun control has historically been used as a way to disarm minorities and political dissidents. The Jews in World War 2 were also not allowed the right to possess weapons.
